Award.AwardTitle: 2015 Graduate Climate Conference (GCC); Woods Hole, Massachusetts; November 6-8, 2015
Award.AbstractNarration: The Graduate Climate Conference will take place Nov 6-8, 2015 at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole MA. The goal of the conference is to foster a scholarly community focused on collaborative research into the nature of climate and the impacts of climate and climate change on society. The conference will bring together students with diverse academic and personal background and offers a supportive atmosphere where they can learn from one another. This opportunity allows graduate students to familiarize themselves with the breadth of climate science as well as the enormous range of tools available to help answer complex questions. Participation from diverse members of the graduate climate science community will be sought. A significant lasting impact of this conference is the participants' interaction with their contemporary early-career colleagues; providing this contact information will increase the speed at which scientific progress can be made by facilitating graduate students with a professional network of young climate scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 9th Graduate Climate Conference (GCC) was held from November 6-8, 2015 at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts. The conference was organized by a team of graduate students from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Program in Atmospheres, Oceans, and Climate, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and Harvard University’s Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences. The purpose of the meeting was to continue to provide a discussion forum for graduate students undertaking research in a broad range of disciplines within the field of climate science. The all-graduate student, single-session format of the conference was designed to encourage new climate scientists to become acquainted with diverse areas and methods of research, and to place their own research in the broader context of climate. The conference provided a unique opportunity for graduate students to present their work in a relaxed, friendly environment, and to develop lasting connections and collaborations with their contemporary early-career colleagues.

In order to attract a diverse pool of applicants, the 2015 GCC was advertised to more than 200 national and international graduate programs in physical sciences, engineering, social sciences, and policy-making. The call for abstracts was also distributed by at least 15 climate-related organizations through their websites and mailing lists, including various programs serving women and underrepresented minorities in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). A total of 211 applications from 27 different countries and 29 US states were received and blindly reviewed by a group of graduate students representing a broad range of disciplines within climate science.

Ninety students from 38 different institutions, including 4 international universities, attended the meeting. Almost half (47%) of the attendees were women. In an optional survey distributed upon registration to the conference, 26% of the participants self-identified as international students and 9% as an underrepresented minority in STEM. In order to broaden accessibility to all qualified students, the cost of lodging, meals, facilities, and local transportation to the conference site was generously funded by NSF and other local institutions. Additionally, 29 attendees (16 of these female) received travel scholarships, representing 51% of all participants traveling from outside of Massachusetts. These grants were distributed depending on need and funding availability. The agenda for the conference included eight oral sessions organized into themes and three mixed-discipline poster sessions. This year’s session topics were Regional Climate, Ecology, Paleoclimate and Cryosphere, Atmospheric Dynamics, Human Dimensions, Ocean Dynamics, Hydrology and Water Resources, and Biogeochemistry. The keynote address was given by Dr. Anne Giblin, the only non-graduate student attendee and senior scientist at the Marine Biological Laboratory. The conference program and all abstracts were posted online at www.graduateclimateconference.com. Participants were encouraged to fill out an optional post-conference survey in which they were asked to rate the conference overall from 1 to 10. The average rating was 9/10.
